moves.1. d4: That's a standard opening move, so it's good. You want to control the centre of the board and this also allows your black bishop to move out.
moves.2. c4: That's a little unusual. Most people would move the king's pawn out or perhaps a knight.
moves.2... dxc4: I thought I might as well take it.
moves.3. Nf3: That's a good move. You want to get your knights and bishops out at this stage.
moves.4. Ne5: One rule of thumb at this stage is not to move a piece more than once. You're trying to get all your pieces out into the middle. You would be better off moving out the other knight or a bishop.
moves.4... e6: This will allow my bishop to come out.
moves.5. Nxc4: Ok, fair enough. You've moved that knight three times now, so you're behind on 'development'.
moves.5... Be7: Out comes my bishop. I can castle now.
moves.6. e3: Not bad, your white bishop can come out now.
moves.6... Nc6: I'm getting my other knight out, which is what you should be doing at this stage.
moves.7. h3: That's a good defensive move. It stops my knight going to g4.
moves.7... O-O: I have castled. In most games you will want to do this to protect your king.
moves.8. Nba3: Ok good, your other knight is out.
moves.8... b6: My idea is to put the bishop on b7 next.
moves.9. Nxb6: Oops, a mistake. You've gained a pawn, but now I can take your knight, which is much more valuable than the pawn.
moves.10. Nb5: I guess that's ok, but you should focus on getting your other pieces out.
moves.10... a6: Threatening the knight. I want it to back off. Knights make me nervous when they're too close!
moves.11. Na3: It's back where it was, so you've wasted time.
moves.12... Qd5: Bringing my queen out into the centre. Quite a bold move because it's vulnerable there, but I felt like it was time to attack.
moves.13. Qd3: Fair enough, but your bishops still haven't joined the party.
moves.13... Rfd8: The rook is now supporting the queen on the d file.
moves.14. Nb4: Your first big mistake. Before you move a piece check that it's going to be safe on that square.
moves.14... Nxb4: Got your other knight and threatening your queen.
moves.15. Qc3: Your queen is still quite vulnerable there.
moves.16. Qxb4: A massive error. The knight was protected by my bishop.
moves.16... Bxb4+: It's pretty much all over for you now.
moves.17... e5: I'm hoping you'll take that pawn because I could win the game next move by going to d1.
moves.18. b3: Not sure why you did that. I guess you could finally move the bishop to b2 next move.
moves.18... exd4: I want to come down the middle with my queen.
moves.19. exd4: I guess you don't have many options there.
moves.19... Qxd4: I should be able to end the game pretty quickly from here. Note that I'm also threatening your rook on a1.
moves.20. Kf3: That was your only choice I think.
moves.20... Nxf2+: I'm attacking the other rook on h1.
moves.22. Kh2: I decide to let you have the knight and...
moves.23. Kxh1: I'm not that bothered because now I've got your bishop.
moves.23... Qxc1: Your other bishop is trapped now. You can't move it out of the way because you will expose the king to check.
moves.24. Kh2: You could have moved your king to g1 to protect the bishop.
moves.24... Qxf1: Now it's dead and you're helpless.
moves.25. h4: It's all over now I'm afraid ):

gameName: Chat with the Chess Noob that is Don Jorginho
